title: What are the top science fiction movies ever? - Quora

response.answer_text: “2001” in Cinerama. If you haven’t seen it in Cinerama, you haven’t seen it. Would you say you’d seen “Gravity” if you’d only watched it on your tablet? Even IMAX is no substitute for the magnificence of 3 full sized screens joined seamlessly. I saw it 13 times that way and the immersive quality has no match. I know everything wrong with it—from a science POV especially the way astronauts move on the Moon’s surface and the fact that the ancestral species we come from walked fully upright, not hunched over. And tapirs weren’t found in Africa, nor in deserts. Stuff like that. OTOH even The Martian didn’t capture how humans would move on Mars—like nothing’s been learned about making sci fi movies since then. But what’s right with it trumps (so to speak) its failings. It’s actually science fiction, and the more science you know the more obvious this becomes. One way to tell: the spaceships make no noise in space. The only other sci fi movies I can recall that obey this basic fact are Fobidden Planet and Serenity (both great in their own right).It has gravitas. Have you heard astronauts describe their spacewalks or even sitting in the observation port of the ISS gazing out at the universe? Kubrick, without the benefit of any CGI whatsoever, managed this through the use of deep-focus cameras and incredibly time-consuming cinematography of the deep space sequences. The result is that nothing on this planet’s surface delivers the feeling of the astronaut’s in-space experience like watching the deep space portions of 2001 in Cinerama.Best music score (again with a nod to Forbidden Planet): Richard Strauss, Josef Strauss, Aram Khatchaturian, Gyorgi LIgeti—an awesome combination. Richard Williams is fun, but this is the real deal.Best use of silence. Most notably when Hal unplugs the astronaut and the sounds you’d been hearing from inside the astronaut’s suit abruptly cease, followed by a looong sequence as his body disappers into the infinite night. Conversely, when the other astronaut has to re-enter the space ship the hard way, you don’t hear the explosive bolts but just the sound gradually coming up in the airlock as it shuts and fills with air. This is master film-maker stuff, applied to the science fiction genre.Best FTL visualization—with no GCI!No exposition—like Mary Poppins, Kubrick never explains anything.Best “ship life” portrayal. The shadowboxing sequence is a tour de force.Kubrick understands that there’s more to a movie than plot and action sequences. Atmosphere matters—even when it’s a vacuum.Pity you can’t see 2001 now. Except through, in effect, a pinhole.

Only ten?? No. No, no, no. I can’t do it. Too many masterpieces would have to be amputated out of the list. The best I can do is my top 34 in descending order of preference. Blade Runner (Ridley Scott 1982) A detective must track down ruthless android warriors from off-world who seek to extend their pre-programmed life span. The Matrix (The Wachowski Brothers 1999) A hacker discovers an underground organization who seek to overthrow a world run by AI where humans are enslaved in a virtual reality. Twelve Monkeys (Terry Gilliam 1995) A survivor of a viral apocalypse is held prisoner in an underground bunker. He is given the mission to travel back in time to stop the perpetrators of the release of the deadly virus. Interstellar (Christopher Nolan 2014) Earth’s climate is fast becoming too hostile to sustain life. A team of space pioneers go on a mission to find a hospitable planet where the human race can begin anew. Inception (Christopher Nolan 2010) A group of scientists are hired to commit an act of industrial sabotage by planting an idea which will prevent future success of a rival  Children of Men (Alfonso Cuaron 2006) Humans are no longer able to reproduce and society is falling into chaos. A bureaucrat unexpectedly finds a pregnant woman and fights to help her and her unborn child survive. Solaris (Andrez Tarkovski 1971 & Stephen Soderbergh 2002) A psychologist is sent to a station orbiting a distant planet in order to discover what has caused the crew to go insane. Brazil (Terry Gilliam, 1985) In a retro-future world, a bureaucrat, tries to correct an administrative error, and becomes an enemy of the state Until the End of the World (Wim Wenders, 1991) A traumatized woman agrees to help a man who travels the world on a mission to make neuroexperiential recordings of his travels and family members. He brings the recordings to his father, an exiled neuroscientist who invented the recording device, and who has an exciting new discovery about the transfer of neuroexperiential data between human brains. The Fly (David Cronenberg, 1986) A brilliant but eccentric scientist begins to transform into a giant man/fly hybrid after one of his experiments goes horribly wrong. Johnny Mnemonic (Robert Longo 1995 ) A data courier, literally carrying a data package inside his head, must deliver it before he dies from the burden or is killed by the Yakuza. Altered Carbon (series, Laeta Kalogridis 2018) Set in a future where consciousness is digitized and stored, a prisoner returns to life in a new body and must solve a mind-bending murder to win his freedom. Star Trek Into Darkness (J.J. Abrams 2013) After the crew of the Enterprise find an unstoppable force of terror from within their own organization, Captain Kirk leads a manhunt to a war-zone world to capture a one-man weapon of mass destruction. Arrival (Denis Villeneuve 2016): A linguist is recruited by the military to communicate with alien lifeforms after twelve mysterious spacecrafts land around the world. I, Robot (Alex Proyas 2004): In 2035, a technophobic cop investigates a crime that may have been perpetrated by a robot, which leads to a larger threat to humanity.  Transcendence (Wally Pfister 2014) A scientist's drive for artificial intelligence, takes on dangerous implications when his consciousness is uploaded into one such program. Lucy (Luc Besson 2014): A woman, accidentally caught in a dark deal, turns the tables on her captors and transforms into a merciless warrior evolved beyond human logic. Anon (Andrew Niccol 2018) In a world of augmented reality where privacy and crime no longer exist, a detective must catch a killer who has no data on the identity grid Snowpiercer (Joon-ho Bong 2013) In a future where a failed climate-change experiment kills all life on the planet except for a lucky few who boarded the Snowpiercer, a train that travels around the globe, where a class system emerges. Ender’s Game (Gavin Hood 2013) Young Ender Wiggin is recruited by the International Military to lead the fight against the Formics, a genocidal alien race which nearly annihilated the human race in a previous invasion. TRON Legacy (Joseph Kosinski 2010) The son of a virtual world designer goes looking for his father and ends up inside the digital world that his father designed. He meets his father's corrupted creation and a unique ally who was born inside the digital world. Ex Machina (Alex Garland 2014) A young programmer is selected to participate in a ground-breaking experiment in synthetic intelligence by evaluating the human qualities of a breath-taking humanoid A.I. The Zero Theorem (Terry Gilliam 2013) A hugely talented but socially isolated computer operator is tasked by Management to prove the Zero Theorem: that the universe ends as nothing, rendering life meaningless. Minority Report (Stephen Spielburg 2002) In a future where a special police unit is able to arrest murderers before they commit their crimes, an officer from that unit is himself accused of a future murder. 2001 A Space Odyssey (Stanley Kubick 1968) A space-opera spanning the dawn of man to humanity reaching the stars, 2001: A Space Odyssey tells the story of the Black Monolith, humanity's evolution and the rise of A.I.'s ultimate supercomputer HAL 9000.  Cube (Vincenzo Natali 1997) 6 complete strangers of widely varying personality characteristics are involuntarily placed in an endless maze containing deadly traps. The Martian (Ridley Scott 2015) An astronaut becomes stranded on Mars after his team assume him dead, and must rely on his ingenuity to find a way to signal to Earth that he is alive. Moon (Duncan Stone 2009) Astronaut Sam Bell has a quintessentially personal encounter toward the end of his three-year stint on the Moon, where he, working alongside his computer, GERTY, sends back to Earth parcels of a resource that has helped diminish our planet's power problems. Ready Player One (Steven Spielberg 2018) When the creator of a virtual reality world called the OASIS dies, he releases a video in which he challenges all OASIS users to find his Easter Egg, which will give the finder his fortune. Upside Down (Juan Solanas 2012) Adam and Eden fell in love as teens despite the fact that they live on twinned worlds with gravities that pull in opposite directions. Ten years after a forced separation, Adam sets out on a dangerous quest to reconnect with his love.  Blade Runner 2049 (Denis Villeneuve 2017) A young blade runner's discovery of a long-buried secret leads him to track down former blade runner Rick Deckard, who's been missing for thirty years. Her (Spike Jonze 2013) In a near future, a lonely writer develops an unlikely relationship with an operating system designed to meet his every need. Oblivion (Joseph Kosinski 2013) A veteran assigned to extract Earth's remaining resources begins to question what he knows about his mission and himself. OtherLife (Ben C. Lucas 2013) After inventing a drug that induces time-compressed virtual realities, young Ren grapples with partner Sam over how to use their powerful creation. Special mention to the outstanding series Black Mirror.
